journal-title-group.journal-title: Progress of Theoretical and Experimental Physics

title-group.article-title: Gapless edge modes in (4+1)-dimensional topologically massive tensor gauge theory and anomaly inflow for subsystem symmetry

contrib.aff: Department of Physics, Graduate School of Science, Osaka University, Toyonaka, Osaka 560-0043, Japan

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2022. Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of the Physical Society of Japan.

license.license-p: This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/), which permits unrestricted reuse, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: We consider the (4 + 1)D topologically massive tensor gauge theory. This theory is an analog of the (2 + 1)D topologically massive Maxwell–Chern–Simons theory. If the space has a boundary, we find that a (3 + 1)D gapless theory appears at the boundary. This gapless theory is a chiral version of the (3 + 1)D φ theory. This gapless theory is protected by the anomaly inflow mechanism for subsystem symmetry. We also consider the corner of our topologically massive tensor gauge theory, and find that an infinite number of (1 + 1)D chiral bosons appear at the corner.

sec.title: Introduction and summary
sec.p: Subsystem symmetries are one of the interesting generalizations of symmetry in quantum field theories [1–3]. They play an important role in fracton phases [4–7]. Such exotic systems are mostly investigated in lattice quantum mechanics [8,9]. There are other approaches such as foliated quantum field theory [10,11], infinite-component Chern–Simons theory [12], and continuous quantum field theory [13–21]. In this paper, we employ the continuous quantum field theory approach. More recently, subsystem symmetry and fracton phases have also been studied from the high-energy physics points of views, such as supersymmetry [22], quiver gauge theory [23], and string theory [24].

Another important phenomenon in the recent studies of the topological aspects of quantum field theories is the anomaly inflow mechanism [25]. An example of this anomaly inflow is that a (1 + 1)D chiral boson appears at the boundary of the (2+1)D topologically massive Maxwell–Chern–Simons theory [26,27]. The anomaly of the (1+1)D chiral boson cancels to the anomaly inflow from the (2+1)D bulk, and the total system is anomaly-free. The generalization of this example has been investigated in detail in Ref. [28]. The anomaly inflow mechanism led to the modern understanding of anomalies in terms of higher-dimensional symmetry-protected topological (SPT) phases (see, e.g., Refs. [29,30]).

Combining these two ideas, one may find that subsystem SPT (SSPT) phases are also interesting phases of matter. SSPT phases have been introduced and studied in many papers including Refs. [31–33]. We expect that SSPT phases and anomaly inflow will be useful for understanding the anomalies of subsystem symmetries.

In this paper, we study an example of the SSPT phase and anomaly inflow. We study (4 + 1)D topologically massive tensor gauge theory. This theory is an analog of (3 + 1)D topologically massive Maxwell–Chern–Simons theory. We explicitly construct gapless modes localized at the boundary. They form the chiral version of the (3 + 1)D φ theory. The (3 + 1)D φ-theory resembles the (1 + 1)D free scalar [21]. Thus we expect the chiral version of the φ theory to exist. We find that it appears at the boundary of the topologically massive tensor gauge theory.

This (4 + 1)D topologically massive tensor gauge theory has subsystem symmetry called magnetic center symmetry. We find that the boundary chiral φ theory is robust due to the anomaly inflow mechanism [28] of this magnetic center symmetry.

We also consider the codimension-3 corner-localized modes of the topologically massive tensor gauge theory. We find that an infinite number of (1 + 1)D chiral bosons appear at the corner. The anomaly inflow argument for these corner states is an interesting future problem.

Another interesting future issue is to develop a more precise formulation of the tensor Chern–Simons theory as done in Ref. [28]. In other words, it should be nice to have some sort of differential cohomology and differential K-theory for tensor gauge fields for subsystem symmetries.

The construction of this paper is as follows. In Sect. 2, we set up the topologically massive tensor gauge theory and find the massless chiral φ theory at the boundary of the spacetime. In Sect. 3, we discuss the anomaly inflow for the magnetic center symmetry. In Sect. 4, we consider the corner states of the topologically massive tensor gauge theory and find an infinite number of chiral bosons.
Note added: while writing this manuscript, we noticed that the anomaly inflow mechanism of the chiral φ theory has also been discussed in a recent paper [34].

sec.title: (4+1)D topologically massive tensor gauge theory on spacetime with a boundary
Setup
sec.p: We consider here a 5D non-relativistic quantum field theory. The spacetime coordinates are denoted by xμ, μ = 0, 1, 2, 3, 5. Here, x4 is not used in the Lorentzian signature. It is reserved for Euclidean time.

It is convenient to introduce labels A, B, C, … = 0, ♯, 5,1 and define the derivatives ∂A as
(1) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{0}:=\frac{\partial }{\partial x^0},\quad \partial _{5}:=\frac{\partial }{\partial x^5}, \quad \partial _{\sharp }:=\frac{\partial }{\partial x^1}\frac{\partial }{\partial x^2}\frac{\partial }{\partial x^3}. \end{eqnarray}$$ It is useful to notice the relation for two functions Φ1(x), Φ2(x):
(2) $$\begin{eqnarray} (\partial _{A}\Phi _1)\Phi _2+\Phi _1 (\partial _{A}\Phi _2)=(\text{total derivative}). \end{eqnarray}$$ This relation allows us to perform integration by parts in a closed spacetime.

We introduce a 5D tensor gauge field CA, A = 0, ♯, 5. The gauge transformation is given by
(3) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{A}^{\prime }=C_{A}+\partial _{A}\lambda . \end{eqnarray}$$ Here the parameter λ has the same properties as the φ field in the φ theory in Refs. [18,21]. For example, the periodicity λ ∼ λ + 2π is imposed and a certain discontinuity for λ is allowed.

The gauge invariant field strength GAB is defined as
(4) $$\begin{eqnarray} G_{AB}:=\partial _{A}C_{B}-\partial _{B}C_{A}. \end{eqnarray}$$ We impose Lorentz symmetry in the 05-plane, for simplicity. The tensor Maxwell action is given by
(5) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{M}=\int d^5x\left[ \frac{1}{2h^2}G_{05}^2+\frac{1}{2g^2}G_{\sharp 0}^2-\frac{1}{2g^2}G_{\sharp 5}^2\right], \end{eqnarray}$$ where g and h are real positive coupling constants. Since we only impose the Lorentz symmetry in the 05-plane, there are two coupling constants.

We would also like to consider tensor Chern–Simons theory:
(6) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{\mathrm{CS}}=\frac{k}{4\pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC}C_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C}, \end{eqnarray}$$ where ϵABC is a totally anti-symmetric symbol and ϵ0♯5 = 1. k is an analog of the Chern–Simons level and it must be an integer for the gauge invariance as discussed in Appendix A.

We consider the theory including both the Maxwell term and the Chern–Simons term with k = 1. The total action is given by
(7) $$\begin{eqnarray} S=\int d^5x\left[ \frac{1}{2h^2}G_{05}^2+\frac{1}{2g^2}G_{\sharp 0}^2-\frac{1}{2g^2}G_{\sharp 5}^2+\frac{1}{4\pi }\epsilon ^{ABC}C_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C} \right]. \end{eqnarray}$$ The equations of motion derived from this action are given by
(8) $$\begin{eqnarray} -\frac{1}{h^2}\partial _{0}G_{05}+\frac{1}{g^2}\partial _{\sharp }G_{\sharp 5}+\frac{1}{2\pi }G_{0\sharp }=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(9) $$\begin{eqnarray} \frac{1}{h^2}\partial _{5}G_{05}-\frac{1}{g^2}\partial _{\sharp }G_{\sharp 0} +\frac{1}{2\pi } G_{\sharp 5}=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(10) $$\begin{eqnarray} \frac{1}{g^2}\partial _{0}G_{\sharp 0}-\frac{1}{g^2}\partial _{5}G_{\sharp 5}-\frac{1}{2\pi }G_{05}=0. \end{eqnarray}$$

sec.title: Localized modes at the boundary
sec.p:
Here, we consider the spacetime x5 > 0 with a boundary at x5 = 0. We impose the boundary condition
(11) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{A}|_{x_5=0}=0 \end{eqnarray}$$ up to the gauge transformation at the boundary. It is not only flat but a pure gauge. In other words, all the Wilson loops vanish at the boundary. Even though the theory includes the Chern–Simons term and the spacetime has a boundary, the theory is gauge invariant due to the boundary condition (11).
We want to find the modes localized at this boundary. To do this, we will solve the equations of motion (8), (9), (10) under the boundary condition (11).

We employ the ansatz
(12) $$\begin{eqnarray} G_{\sharp 0}=0 \end{eqnarray}$$ even in the bulk and look for localized solutions. Then the equations of motion (8), (9), (10) are rewritten as
(13) $$\begin{eqnarray} -\frac{1}{h^2}\partial _{0}G_{05}+\frac{1}{g^2}\partial _{\sharp }G_{\sharp 5}=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(14) $$\begin{eqnarray} \frac{1}{h^2}\partial _{5}G_{05} +\frac{1}{2\pi } G_{\sharp 5}=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(15) $$\begin{eqnarray} -\frac{1}{g^2}\partial _{5}G_{\sharp 5}-\frac{1}{2\pi }G_{05}=0, \end{eqnarray}$$ respectively. We solve Eq. (15) for G05 and substitute it into Eq. (14). Then we obtain
(16) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{5}^2 G_{\sharp 5}=m^2 G_{\sharp 5},\qquad m:=\frac{hg}{2\pi }\gt 0. \end{eqnarray}$$ For a normalizable solution, this equation implies
(17) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{5}G_{\sharp 5}=-mG_{\sharp 5}. \end{eqnarray}$$ In other words, the x5 dependence of G♯5 is $G_{\sharp 5}\propto e^{-mx^5}$. Similarly we solve Eq. (14) for G♯5 and substitute it into Eq. (15). Then, taking the normalizability into account, we obtain
(18) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{5}G_{0 5}=-mG_{0 5}. \end{eqnarray}$$ By substituting Eqs. (17) and (18) into Eqs. (14) and (15), we obtain
(19) $$\begin{eqnarray} G_{05}-\alpha G_{\sharp 5}=0,\quad \alpha :=\frac{h}{g}. \end{eqnarray}$$

We choose the C5 = 0 gauge. Since C0, C♯ are a pure gauge at the boundary x5 = 0, they are written using a φ field with the periodicity φ ∼ φ + 2π of the φ theory at the boundary as
(20) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{0}|_{x^5=0}=\partial _{0}\varphi ,\quad C_{\sharp }|_{x^5=0}=\partial _{\sharp }\varphi . \end{eqnarray}$$ The x5 dependence is determined by Eqs. (17), (18), and we obtain
(21) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{0}=\partial _{0}\varphi e^{-mx^5},\quad C_{\sharp }=\partial _{\sharp }\varphi e^{-mx^5}. \end{eqnarray}$$

Equation (13) reads
(22) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{0}^2\varphi -\alpha ^2 \partial _{\sharp }^2\varphi =0. \end{eqnarray}$$ This is the equation of motion of the φ theory [21] (see also Ref. [22]). Actually, our φ field must satisfy a stronger constraint from Eq. (19):
(23) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{0}\varphi -\alpha \partial _{\sharp }\varphi =0. \end{eqnarray}$$ This constraint implies that these boundary-localized modes form the chiral φ theory.

Here let us comment on the Chern–Simons level. In this paper, we choose k = +1 and obtain the boundary-localized chiral modes. If we consider the case with k = −1, we obtain boundary-localized anti-chiral modes: ∂0φ + α∂♯φ = 0. If we consider |k| > 1, the story is quite different. The bulk theory is no longer in an SSPT phase but has some topological degrees of freedom. Moreover, we cannot impose the Dirichlet boundary condition (11). It would be interesting to study this case in more detail.

sec.title: Anomaly inflow
sec.p: In the previous section, we have shown that the (3 + 1)D chiral φ theory appears at the boundary of the (4 + 1)D topologically massive tensor gauge theory. In this section, we want to show that this boundary theory is robust due to the anomaly inflow mechanism for subsystem symmetry.

In this subsection, we use the Euclidean formulation. The coordinates are xμ, μ = 1, …, 5. x4 is Euclidean time. It is convenient to use labels A, B, C = ♯, 4, 5. The symbol ϵABC is totally anti-symmetric and ϵ♯45 = 1. The Euclidean action of the topologically massive tensor gauge theory is given by
(24) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{E}=\int d^5x\left[ \frac{1}{2h^2}G_{45}^2+\frac{1}{2g^2}G_{\sharp 4}^2+\frac{1}{2g^2}G_{\sharp 5}^2+\frac{i}{4\pi }\epsilon ^{ABC}C_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C} \right]. \end{eqnarray}$$

sec.title: Magnetic center symmetry
sec.p:
We have a global symmetry called “magnetic center symmetry” in the topologically massive tensor gauge theory (7). The current of this symmetry is given by
(25) $$\begin{eqnarray} M^{A}:= \frac{i}{2\pi }\epsilon ^{ABC}\partial _{B}C_{C}. \end{eqnarray}$$ This current satisfies the conservation law:
(26) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{A}M^{A}=0. \end{eqnarray}$$ This magnetic center symmetry is a subsystem symmetry. This magnetic center symmetry is preserved even if we introduce a boundary at x5 = 0 with the boundary condition (11).

Let us consider gauging this symmetry by introducing a background gauge field AA and adding the term
(27) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{\mathrm{couple}}=\int d^5 x A_{A}M^{A}=\frac{i}{2\pi }\int d^5 x \epsilon ^{ABC}A_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C}. \end{eqnarray}$$ The gauge transformation is given by
(28) $$\begin{eqnarray} A^{\prime }_{A}=A_{A}+\partial _{A}\rho , \end{eqnarray}$$ where ρ is the parameter of the gauge transformation. In this paper, we only consider infinitesimal gauge transformation for the background gauge field, and thus ρ is an infinitesimal function on the spacetime. The term (27) is invariant under the infinitesimal gauge transformation (28) if the spacetime does not have a boundary.

sec.title: Effective theory of the background gauge field
sec.p:
Let us consider the topologically massive tensor gauge theory coupled to the background magnetic center symmetry gauge field. The partition function with the background gauge field is given by
(29) $$\begin{eqnarray} Z[A]=\int DCe^{-S_{E}(C)-S_{\mathrm{couple}}(C,A)}=:|Z[A]|e^{-S_{\mathrm{eff}}(A)}. \end{eqnarray}$$ The phase functional $e^{-S_{\mathrm{eff}}}$ characterizes the SSPT phase. We only consider the low-energy limit and therefore ignore the Maxwell term. We can rewrite the action as
(30) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{E}+S_{\mathrm{couple}}&=& \frac{i}{4\pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC}(C_{A}+A_{A})\partial _{B}(C_{C}+A_{C}) -\frac{i}{4 \pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC} A_{A}\partial _{B}A_{C} \\ &&+\;\frac{i}{4\pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC}\partial _{B}( A_{A}C_{C}). \end{eqnarray}$$ The first term will disappear if we redefine the C field and integrate it out. The second term remains and becomes part of Seff. The third term is a total derivative and therefore we can ignore it at least perturbatively. This is enough since we are considering the perturbative anomaly. Then, Seff is given by
(31) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{\mathrm{eff}}(A)=-\frac{i}{4 \pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC} A_{A}\partial _{B}A_{C}. \end{eqnarray}$$ This is gauge invariant if the spacetime is closed.

Once we consider the spacetime with a boundary, the effective action (31) is no longer gauge invariant. Let us consider the spacetime x5 > 0 with a boundary x5 = 0. Then the gauge transformation of Eq. (31) is given by
(32) $$\begin{eqnarray} \delta S_{\mathrm{eff}}(A)=\frac{i}{4 \pi }\int _{x^5=0} d^4x \epsilon ^{5BC} \rho \partial _{B}A_{C}. \end{eqnarray}$$ This should cancel the anomaly of the chiral φ theory. Therefore, the chiral φ theory at the boundary is robust due to this anomaly inflow mechanism.

sec.title: Localized solution at the corner
sec.p: In this section, we consider the topologically massive tensor gauge theory (7) in the spacetime xi > 0, i = 1, 2, 3. Here, we go back to the Lorentzian signature.

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p:
First, we discuss the boundary conditions. We impose the boundary condition such that the gauge symmetry (3) is preserved. The gauge transformation of the action (7) is calculated as
(33) $$\begin{eqnarray} S^{\prime }-S=\frac{1}{4\pi }\int d^5 x \Delta \mathcal {L}, \end{eqnarray}$$
(34) $$\begin{eqnarray} \Delta \mathcal {L}&=&\epsilon ^{ABC}\left[(C_{A}+\partial _{A}\lambda )\partial _{B}(C_C+\partial _{C}\lambda ) -C_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C} \right] \\ &=&\epsilon ^{ABC}\partial _{A}\lambda \partial _{B}C_C =\partial _{0}\lambda G_{\sharp 5}+\partial _{5}\lambda G_{0\sharp }+\partial _{\sharp }\lambda G_{50} \\ &=&\partial _{0}(\lambda G_{\sharp 5})+\partial _{5}(\lambda G_{0\sharp }) +\partial _{\sharp }\lambda G_{50}+\lambda \partial _{\sharp } G_{50}. \end{eqnarray}$$ In the last expression, the first and second total derivative terms vanish since our spacetime does not have a boundary in the x0, x5 directions. Let us look at the third and fourth terms more carefully:
(35) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{\sharp }\lambda G_{50}+\lambda \partial _{\sharp } G_{50} =\partial _{1}(\partial _2\partial _3\lambda G_{50}) -\partial _{2}(\partial _3\lambda \partial _1 G_{50}) +\partial _{3}(\lambda \partial _1\partial _2 G_{50}). \end{eqnarray}$$ Thus the boundary term at x1 = 0 becomes
(36) $$\begin{eqnarray} S^{\prime }-S &=&-\frac{1}{4\pi }\int _{x^1=0} d x^0 dx^2 dx^3 dx^5 (\partial _2\partial _3\lambda G_{50})+\cdots \\ &=&-\frac{1}{4\pi }\int _{x^1=0} d x^0 dx^2 dx^3 dx^5 [\lambda \partial _2 \partial _3 G_{50} -\partial _3(\lambda \partial _2 G_{50})+\partial _2(\partial _3 \lambda G_{50})]+\cdots . \end{eqnarray}$$ Here ⋅⋅⋅ represents the other boundary terms at x2 = 0, x3 = 0 and corners. The first term in the integrand must vanish to be gauge invariant. Therefore we impose the boundary condition
(37) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _2\partial _3 G_{50}=0\quad \text{at } x^1=0. \end{eqnarray}$$ The third term of the integrand in Eq. (36) contributes to the corner x1 = x2 = 0. In order to eliminate this contribution, we impose the boundary condition
(38) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _3 G_{50}=0\quad \text{at } x^1=x^2=0. \end{eqnarray}$$ Here we perform integration by parts again. Finally, we consider the corner x1 = x2 = x3 = 0. The boundary term at this corner is
(39) $$\begin{eqnarray} S^{\prime }-S =-\frac{1}{4\pi }\int _{x^1=x^2=x^3=0} d x^0 dx^5 \lambda G_{50}+\cdots . \end{eqnarray}$$ Since λ may have winding, we impose not only G50 = 0 but (C0, C5) is a pure gauge in order to be gauge invariant.

Let us summarize these boundary conditions including permutations of x1, x2, x3. Let i, j, k = 1, 2, 3 all be different labels. Then we impose the boundary conditions:
(40) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _j\partial _k G_{50}=0\quad \text{at } x^i=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(41) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _k G_{50}=0\quad \text{at } x^i=x^j=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(42) $$\begin{eqnarray} (C_0,C_5) \text{ is a pure gauge at } x^1=x^2=x^3=0. \end{eqnarray}$$ The gauge symmetry is preserved due to these boundary conditions.

sec.title: Corner-localized modes
sec.p:
In this setup, we want to find the modes localized at the corner x1 = x2 = x3 = 0. We employ an ansatz G05 = 0 in the whole spacetime. Then the equations of motion (8), (9), (10) become
(43) $$\begin{eqnarray} \frac{1}{g^2} \partial _{\sharp }G_{\sharp 5}-\frac{1}{2\pi } G_{\sharp 0}=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(44) $$\begin{eqnarray} -\frac{1}{g^2} \partial _{\sharp }G_{\sharp 0}+\frac{1}{2\pi }G_{\sharp 5}=0, \end{eqnarray}$$
(45) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{0}G_{\sharp 0}-\partial _{5} G_{\sharp 5}=0. \end{eqnarray}$$ By solving Eq. (44) in terms of G♯5 and substituting it into Eq. (43), we find
(46) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{\sharp }^2 G_{\sharp 0}=\frac{g^4}{(2\pi )^2} G_{\sharp 0}. \end{eqnarray}$$ A normalizable solution must satisfy
(47) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{\sharp }G_{\sharp 0}=-\frac{g^2}{2\pi }G_{\sharp 0}. \end{eqnarray}$$ By solving Eq. (43) in terms of G♯0 and substituting it into Eq. (44), we find that a normalizable solution satisfies
(48) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{\sharp }G_{\sharp 5}=-\frac{g^2}{2\pi }G_{\sharp 5}. \end{eqnarray}$$ We substitute these equations into Eqs. (43) and (44), and obtain
(49) $$\begin{eqnarray} G_{\sharp 5}+G_{\sharp 0}=0. \end{eqnarray}$$ We choose the C♯ = 0 gauge and find the solutions:
(50) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{0}&=&\partial _{0}\phi (x^0,x^5)\exp (-m_1x^1-m_2x^2-m_3x^3),\\ C_{5}&=&\partial _{5}\phi (x^0,x^5)\exp (-m_1x^1-m_2x^2-m_3x^3), \end{eqnarray}$$ where m1, m2, m3 are real positive constants that satisfy
(51) $$\begin{eqnarray} m_1,m_2,m_3\gt 0,\quad m_1m_2m_3=\frac{g^2}{2\pi }. \end{eqnarray}$$ Equation (49) leads to a constraint for ϕ(x0, x5):
(52) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{0}\phi +\partial _5\phi =0. \end{eqnarray}$$ This constraint implies that ϕ is a (1 + 1)D chiral boson.
Since there are an infinite number of possible m1, m2, m3 satisfying Eq. (51), we conclude that there are an infinite number of chiral bosons at the corner.

The author also thanks the Yukawa Institute for Theoretical Physics at Kyoto University. Discussions during the YITP workshop YITP-W-21-04 on “Strings and Fields 2021” were useful in completing this work. This work was supported in part by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number 21K03574.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Open Access funding: SCOAP3.

app.title: Appendix A. Level of the tensor Chern–Simons theory
app.p:
In this appendix, we argue that k must be an integer in the tensor Chern–Simons theory:
(A1) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{\mathrm{CS}}=\frac{ik}{4\pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC}C_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C}. \end{eqnarray}$$ We follow the analogous argument to Ref. [35]. We only consider the spacetime manifold T5 in which all xM, M = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 are periodic. We consider gauge invariance of the theory in the following two gauge field configurations:

list-item.p: One unit of tensor electric flux in 1234-space.
One unit of the usual electric flux in the 45-plane.

app.p:
Let us start with the first configuration. This implies that
(A2) $$\begin{eqnarray} \int d^4 x(\partial _{\sharp }C_{4}-\partial _{4}C_{\sharp }) = 2\pi . \end{eqnarray}$$ For example, we can choose C♯, C4 as
(A3) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{4}=0,\qquad C_{\sharp }=-\partial _{\sharp }f(x^1,x^2,x^3) \frac{x^4}{\ell _4}, \end{eqnarray}$$
(A4) $$\begin{eqnarray} f(x^1,x^2,x^3)&:=&2\pi \Bigg [ \frac{x^1x^2x^3}{\ell _1 \ell _2 \ell _3} -\frac{x^1x^2}{\ell _1\ell _2}\theta (x^3) -\frac{x^2x^3}{\ell _2\ell _3}\theta (x^1) -\frac{x^3x^1}{\ell _3\ell _1}\theta (x^2) \\ &&+\;\frac{x^1}{\ell _1}\theta (x^2)\theta (x^3) +\frac{x^2}{\ell _2}\theta (x^3)\theta (x^1) +\frac{x^3}{\ell _3}\theta (x^1)\theta (x^2) \Bigg ], \end{eqnarray}$$ where ℓi denotes the periodicity of xi as xi ∼ xi + ℓi, and θ(x) denotes the Heaviside step function. This f is a winding number 1 field configuration of the φ theory [21]. We also introduce flat C5 with a parameter u given by
(A5) $$\begin{eqnarray} \int dx_5 C_5 = 2\pi u. \end{eqnarray}$$ We continuously change u from 0 to 1 and see how SCS changes by this deformation. Notice that configurations u = 0, 1 are connected by a gauge transformation and they must be identical up to $2\pi i \mathbb {Z}$ in order to have gauge invariance. It is also useful to notice that, by an arbitrary small change of the gauge field δCA, the change of the action is written as
(A6) $$\begin{eqnarray} \delta S_{\mathrm{CS}}=\frac{ik}{2\pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC}\delta C_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C}. \end{eqnarray}$$ By using this equation, we obtain
(A7) $$\begin{eqnarray} \partial _{u}S_{\mathrm{CS}}&=&\frac{ik}{2\pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{ABC}\partial _{u} C_{A}\partial _{B}C_{C} =\frac{ik}{2\pi }\int d^5x \epsilon ^{5ab}\partial _{u} C_{5}\partial _{a}C_{b} \\ &=&\frac{ik}{2\pi }\int d^4x \epsilon ^{ab}\partial _{a}C_{b}\; \partial _{u}\int dx^5 C_5 =2\pi i k,\qquad (a,b=\sharp ,4), \end{eqnarray}$$ and therefore
(A8) $$\begin{eqnarray} S_{\mathrm{CS}}|_{u=1}-S_{\mathrm{CS}}|_{u=0}=\int _{0}^{1}du \partial _{u}S_{\mathrm{CS}}=2\pi i k. \end{eqnarray}$$ As a result, we find that k must be an integer.

Next, let us consider the second configuration. In this configuration,
(A9) $$\begin{eqnarray} \int dx^4dx^5(\partial _4 C_5 - \partial _5 C_4) = 2\pi \end{eqnarray}$$ is satisfied. For example, we can choose
(A10) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{4}=0,\quad C_{5}=\frac{2\pi }{\ell _{4}\ell _{5}}x^4. \end{eqnarray}$$ Let us consider a gauge transformation parameter λ1 that only depends on x1, x2, x3 and satisfies
(A11) $$\begin{eqnarray} \int dx^1dx^2dx^3 \partial _{\sharp }\lambda _1=2\pi . \end{eqnarray}$$ This is a φ field configuration with winding number 1 [21]. We consider C♯ with a real parameter v:
(A12) $$\begin{eqnarray} C_{\sharp }= v \partial _{\sharp } \lambda _1. \end{eqnarray}$$ The configurations v = 0, 1 are connected by a gauge transformation, and thus they must be identical up to $2\pi i \mathbb {Z}$. By the same argument as the first configuration, we find that k must be an integer.

fn.p: It may become clearer why we call the C field a “tensor” gauge field if we use the label 123 instead of ♯. However, we do not use this notation to avoid confusion when many such labels are used at the same place.
